title: How does your body convert oxygen into carbon dioxide? What does your body specifically use oxygen for, and why does it need to convert it into carbon dioxide? - Quora

response.answer_text: (1) How does your body convert oxygen into carbon dioxide? (2) What does your body specifically use oxygen for, and (3) why does it need to convert it into carbon dioxide? Short answers: Oxygen is not “converted into CO[math]_2[/math]”: Glycolysis (see below) converts glucose into pyruvate, the energy of which mitochondria (cellular respiration) then use to synthesize ATP.In a series of redox reactions called oxidative phosphorylation (at the end of the electron transport chain (ETC)), oxygen is the final electron acceptor, with two protons (hydrogen ions) and two electrons forming H[math]_2[/math]O.See 1.Overall reaction: C[math]_6[/math]H[math]_{12}[/math]O[math]_6[/math] [math]+[/math] 6 O[math]_2[/math] [math]→[/math] 6 CO[math]_2[/math] [math]+[/math] 6 H[math]_2[/math]O [math]+[/math] energy ([math]≈[/math] 36 ATP molecules).  Glycolysis (Glucose to Pyruvate) Overview diagram lifted from www.pinterest.com page Chapter 26: Nutrition & Metabolism.  Aerobic Respiration Products infograph lifted from smashey.wordpress.com page Biology Class Page 8.  See also butane.chem.uiuc.edu article Oxidation States in Sugar Reactions. Thanks for asking, Kiley!

It’s a bit complicated to explain in a Quora answer, but your body uses oxygen to convert glucose to carbon dioxide, water, and adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This is the fuel that your body (and most other cellular organisms) runs on. Adenosine triphosphate - Wikipedia

Body doesn't converts oxygen into carbon oxide. The oxygen you inhale is converted into water while the food you ate contains carbon and that carbon is converted into carbon dioxide. It needs to do this because this process is responsible for giving you energy from the food you ate.

The answer is not simple, and it involves the Krebs cycle of energy metabolism in cells. Citric acid cycle - Wikipedia Nature has evolved this cycle over a long period of time, as one of the most efficient (therefore dominant) mechanisms for life to process energy. Biochemistry meets Darwin.
